3:
The superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs, it appeared to be common: it did not extend to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches. At that time, the idea becoming prevalent that a Latin body could not survive if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West, it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the vampires mysteriously infested a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened—and their veins became distended to such a state of completeness, as to cause... explanations.

“Blood sucks—and their veins became distended to such a state of completion, causing the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies and even from the orifices of their skins.”
4: In the London Journal of March 1732, there is a curious account of a particular case of vampirism, which is stated to have occurred at Madra, in Hungary. It appears that upon examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed that, about five years prior, a certain Duke, named Arnold Paul, had been accused of saying that at Cassovia, the front of the Turkish forces had been tormented by a vampire, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil by eating some of the earth from the vampire’s grove, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming the vampire himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many people complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. was accused by others of murdering four people by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants who had consulted their agni (or horoscope) took the body, and found it fresh, entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and red blood. Proof of this was obtained, and they resorted to the usual remedy. A stake was driven through the bear and body of Arnold Paul, and he is reported to have cried dreadfully as he had been olive. This was done, and then their heads were cut off, burned their bodies, and the remains were thrown into their grave. The same measures were adopted with those who had previously died from varivpyrism, lest they should, in turn, become contemptible towards others who survived them.”
5: The universal belief is that a person sucked by a vampire becomes a vampire himself, and he sucks in turn.

9: Mr. Southey introduced his wild ballad "Thalaba," the vampire corpse of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave to torment her best loved while in existence. This cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinful nature of her life; she is portrayed throughout the whole tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The veracity of the Tourncf0rt gives a long account in his travels of several astonishing cases of vampirism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides anecdotes and traditional narratives illustrating its effects, has put forth some learned disagreements, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.

13: The same time, there came to London a gentleman named Aubrey: he was an orphan left with only a sister in possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. He was left to himself by guardians, who thought their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to the care of mercenary sub-ventures. He cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had that highromantic feeling of honor and candor, which daily ruins so many milliner's apprentices. He believed all to sympathize with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown in by providence merely for the picturesque effect of the scene, as we see in romances; he thought that the misery of a cottage was merely consisting in the wounding of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various colored patches. was better adapted to the painter’s eye than anyone else because of their irregular folds and various colored patches. “Previously, Aubrey had not had the opportunity to study Lord Ruthven’s character, and now he found that though many of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives for his conduct. His companion was generous in his generosity; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate needs. However, Aubrey could not avoid remarking that it was not upon the vicious, reduced to idleness and misfortune, that he based his claims;—these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers. But when the prodigal came to ask something, not to relieve his needs, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him further into his inequity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the vicious.” the viciousness that generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the vicious indigent. There was one circumstance about his Lordship, which was still more impressive upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to suffering, or sunk to the lowest and most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought the centers of all fashionable venues; he entered into the spirit of the faro table; he bet, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around; it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a numerous family; then his very wish. – this apparent abstruseness of mind ceased, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of a cat while dallying with the hal fox-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, torn from the circle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the state that had drawn him within the reach of this friend; while many a father sat far away, amidst the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immense wealth, to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruin of many, the last gilt he had just snatched from the clutches of the insolent; this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not capable of overcoming the cunning of the more experienced. explanations.

“Knowledge, which was not, however, capable of inspiring the experience of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent it to his friend, and begged him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not try to his own profit;—but he delayed it—for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him. However, this never occurred. Lord Ruthuen in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of wondering to break that mystery, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.”
16: They soon arrived at Romc, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, while he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guards, the latter astonished him; if it had been stronger, he would have believed that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guards insisted upon his immediate departure from his friend, and urged that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered that his contempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character, but that he had required… had required to enhance his gratification that his husband, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of sullicenced virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in that, all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had since his departure thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
17: Aubrey determined upon leaving one whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest his eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext to abandon him altogether, intending to watch him more closely and to let no slight circumstances pass by unnoted. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavoring to work upon the experience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it was seldom that an unmarried female was met with in society; he was therefore obliged to marry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey’s eye followed him in all his winding ways, and soon discovered that an assignment had been appointed, which would most likely and in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the Lord Ruthven’s apartment and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about that very night. Lord Ruthven answered that his intentions were such as he thought would be upon such an occasion, and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, he laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note to say that from that moment he must declare that accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his service to seek other apartments, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordship. The assignment was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey’s intervention.

The light step of Ianthe often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kafhmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, shimmering as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just deciphered upori an almost erased tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. While he drew the remains of which he wished to preserve for his future hours, she would stand by and watch the magic effects of his pencil, tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, and paint, to him in all the glowing colors of youthful memory, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subject that had evidentIy made a greater impression upon her mind, she would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. 19: Aubrey began to attoch himself more deeply, and to Ianthe; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart. While he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more and more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself often from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained. But he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the surroundings, while in his mind, he retained an image that seemed to be alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. Ianthe was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank and innocent being he had first known. Next morning Aubrey set off on his excursion unattended. He was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, Ianthe came to the side of his horse and earnestly begged him to return, before night allowed the power of these birds to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in these warm climates, so rapidly gathered into a tremendous mass, and paraded all their rage upon the devoted country. At last, however, he mounted his horse and determined to make up by speed for his delay; but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins, and ere he had advanced far, the power of the star well above—its echoing thunder. explanations.

“Night begins; and ere he had advanced far, the power of the starlight wolf above—its echoing thunder had scarcely an interval of rest—its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue frozen lightning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly, his horse took right, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a bundle that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the hundreds, for a moment, silenced, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery as a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound;—he was startled: but, roused by the…” was a mockery, an awful laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled, but, roused by the thunder that again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness; however, the sound guided him. He appeared to be unseen; for, though he called, the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, “Again baffled!” to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grooved by one whose strength seemed superhuman. Determined to sell his life dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain; he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground – his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his thigh – when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave light in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving…” rating through the hole, that gave light in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in moment the crash of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those who entered. The light of their torches fell upon the walls, and the thatch was loaded with every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey, they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries. He was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought him to a lifeless course. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was out a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side.” his side. There was no color upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attached as the life that once dwelt there: upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to this, the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A vampire! a vampire!" A little was formed, and Audrey was laid by the side of who had lately been his object of so many bright and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had lived within her. He knew not his thoughts – his mind was numb and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy – he held almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search for her husband. Their lamenting cries, “They said,” they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child’s death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the course. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.”
21:
Aubrey being possessed by a most violent fever, he was often delirious. In the intervals, he would appear before Lord Ruth Ven and upon Ianthe—by some unaccountable combination, he seemed to beg of his former companion to save the being he loved. At other times he would incant upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, at this time, arrived in Athens and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of Aubrey’s state, immediately placed himself in the same house and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was frightened and startled at the sight of the image he had now come to see with that of a vampire—but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implicitly implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. explanations.

“Still more by attention, anxiety, and care, he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared as an apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence began to slow, he again gradually retired into the same state of mirth, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon her; with a smile of malicious exultation playing upon his lips: he did not know why, but this smiled haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid’s recovery, Lord Ruthven was clearly engaged in watching the still waters raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the motionless fun; indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid her eyes.”
22:
Aubrey’s mind, by this block, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lard Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighborhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the ruins, his Ianthe form stood by his side—if he sought it in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the most delicate violet; then suddenly turning round, he would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded thigh. He determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. explanations.

“Taken by him during his illness, they should visit those parts of Greece that had not yet been seen. They traveled in every direction, and sought every spot to which recollection could be attached: but though they had lened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but gradually they slighted these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, whose interest was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus reglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they traveled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as defense. Upon entering, however, a narrow gorge, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighboring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were.” startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the report of several guns. In an instant, their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering bank of the defile; but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insulting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to resisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take hold in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they left the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance, and, no longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around. explanations.

“Longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers’ faces around him – bis guards having, upon Lord Ruthven’s being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.”
23:
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighboring cabin; having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence – they being content merely to guard the entrance until his comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthuen's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed unconscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him; but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness – "Assist me! you may save me – you may do more than that – I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence a little as that of the passing day; but you may save his honor, his friend's honor."—“How? Let me how?” Aubrey.
I need a little—my life ebbs away—I cannot explain the whole—but if you would conceal all your knowledge from me, my honor were free from stain in the world’s mouth—and if my death were unknown for some time in England—I—I—but life.
It shall not be known.
Swear! cried the dying man, raising himself with vehement violence, “Swear by all your soul, reveres, by all your nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day, you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. “His eyes opened bursting from their sockets: “I swear!” said Aubrey; he sank laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.

“A retired man rested, but did not sleep. Many circumstances surrounding his acquaintance with this man arose in his mind, and he did not know why. When he remembered his own sorrow, a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he held the corpse, when a robber met him and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by himself or his comrades, upon his own side of a neighboring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several men, determined to go and investigate it upon the spot where it lay. She arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores, and he hosted the manse of his parents, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. Miss Aubrey had not that winning grudge which gained the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. Lord Ruthven called the morning after the drawing-room, and he had been refused by every other person. When he heard of Aubrey’s illness, he understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by constant attendance and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his welfare, he gradually wore the ear of Miss Avery. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and toils to recover—he could speak of himself as an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents;—in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent’s art, or such was the will. soothing and agreeable accents; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent’s art, or so was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder ranch falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother’s deranged state,) which wa to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.”

“In sailing through the Greek Archipelago, on board one of His Majesty’s vessels, in the year 1822, we put into the harbor of Myteleune, in the island of that name. The beauty of this place and the plentiful supply of cattle and vegetables always had there, induced many British vessels to visit it – both men of war and merchants. Though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, we ourselves took a walk to the cave called Homer’s School and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he came from Scio with an English lord, who had been in the island’s sour days previous to our arrival in his felucca.” must have an English lord, who lest the dreary days preceding our arrival on his felucca. “He engaged me as a pilot,” said the Greek, “and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Milena, where I am likely to get married. He was odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old mill in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zechines for it (about £250 English currency), and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he is in his felucca very often to the different islands.”
40:
Your output should only be the cleaned text, without any additional comments or explanations.

“This account excitedour cvriosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our country resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the manor. It consisted of four apartments on the ground floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting room, and a bedroom, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain green-stained walls, maple tables on either side, a large myrtle in the center, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa completed the furnishings. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs and an empty bookcase. There were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedroom had merely a largo mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed coton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece.” Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman’s chest in the cellar; it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet above the recess lay Voltaire’s, Shakespeare’s, Boileau’s, and Rousseau’s works complete; Volney’s Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman’s in the Germari language; Klopstock’s Messiah; Kotzebue’s novels; Schiller’s play of the Robbers; Milton’s Paradise Lost, an Italian editon, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of those books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was largely written over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
41: The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but, he said, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular that if I moved one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; others, however, were very good. I once did him a service, and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty zechin, which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the woods, and whom the lord brought her from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
42: The appearance of the house externally pleased. The portico in the front was fifteen paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with six plainth and fret-work corniches, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably larger than the rooms. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine tapestry, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house tops are furnished, upon which the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
43: On the left hand, as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges, and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large Myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, where we were told that the lord passed merry of his evenings and nights until twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying," and he was very devoted, "and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
44:
The view from this seat, what may determined "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcaia, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woads north of the mountain's base. The sea was smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty oaks and palm trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studdying the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude; none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Candia. "The Armeniari," said over the conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If..." explanations.

“conductor said, ‘could tell, but I am sure he would not,’ — ‘And cannot you tell, old friend?’ said I — ‘If I could,’ sald he, ‘I dared not.’ We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town, we learned several particulars of the isolated lord. He portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testament to the father’s children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learned, which our old friend at the altar thought proper not to lose, was that he had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lard was often seen walking on the sea shore, and he had bought her a piano forte, and taught her himself the use of it.”

“Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful isle of Mytelene; our imaginations were all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had money; he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those ecclecticities which mark peculiar genius. We arrived at Palermo, and all our doubts were dispelled. Failing company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of Wyatt’s, who had been traveling in Egypt and Greece, “the individual,” said he, “about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Mytelene.” We had never then heard of his lordship’s fame, as we had been some years from home; but “Child Harolde” being put into our hands, we recognized the recluse of Calca in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mytelene on some future day; but to me that day will never.” explanations.

“ourselvef with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordship’s good reputation, which has been grossly slanderous. He has been described as an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to soothe its sorrows, or adding to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse; all the finer feelings of the heart, as elegantly depicted in his lordship’s poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions; and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whose heart religion has set her seal, and over whose head benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing “traits” without feeling proud of him as a countryman.” man can resist the preceding pleasing “traits” without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be cautioned, particularly when directed against a man’s moral integrity; and whoever dares to justify themselves before that awful tribunal, where all must appear, shall censure the errors as a fellow mortal.” Lord Byron’s character is worthy of his genius. To do good secretly and shun the world’s applause is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self- approving conscience.
